sen.j: 後光明天皇（ごこうみょうてんのう、寛永10年3月12日（1633年4月20日） - 承応3年9月20日（1654年10月30日））は江戸時代の第110代天皇（在位：寛永20年10月3日（1643年11月14日) - 承応3年9月20日（1654年10月30日））。
sen.e: Emperor Go-Komyo (April 20th, 1633 - October 30th, 1654) was the 110th Emperor during Edo period. (his reign was November 14th, 1643 - October 30th, 1654.)
Emperor Go-Komyo (April 20, 1633 - October 30, 1654), the 110th Emperor, reigned during the Edo period (from November 14, 1643 to October 30, 1654).
Emperor Gokomyo (April 20, 1633 - October 30, 1654), the 110th Emperor, reigned during the Edo period (from November 14, 1643 to October 30, 1654).

sen.j: 幼名を素鵞宮、諱を紹仁（つぐひと）という。
sen.e: His name from childhood was Suga no Miya and posthumous name was Tsuguhito.
His name from childhood was Suga no Miya, and his posthumous name was Tsuguhito.
His name from childhood was Suganomiya, and his personal name was Tsuguhito.
sen.cmt: 諱をpersonal nameとしました。 Suganomiya としました。

sen.j: 後水尾天皇の第四皇子。
sen.e: He was the forth Prince of Emperor Go-Mizunoo.
He was the fourth prince of Emperor Go-Mizunoo.
He was the fourth prince of Emperor Gomizunoo.

sen.j: 母は、贈左大臣園基任の娘、壬生院・藤原光子。
sen.e: His mother was the Minister of the Right, posthumously conferred, Mototo SONO's daughter, Mibu in FUJIWARA no Mitsuko.
His mother was Mibu in FUJIWARA no Mitsuko, the daughter of the minister of the right (posthumously conferred) Mototo SONO.
His mother was Mibu in FUJIWARA no Mitsuko, the daughter of the Sadaijin (Minister of the Left), Mototo SONO.
sen.cmt: right→ left"minister of the left"→"Sadaijin (Minister of the Left)"に変更しました。

sen.j: 養母は父帝の中宮徳川和子（東福門院）。
sen.e: His mother in law was the second consort of the Emperor, Kazuko TOKUGAWA. (Tofuku mon in)
His mother-in-law was the second consort of the Emperor, Kazuko TOKUGAWA (Tofuku mon-in).
His mother-in-law was the second consort of the Emperor, Masako TOKUGAWA (Tofukumonin).

sen.j: 明正天皇は異母姉。
sen.e: His half older sister is Emperor Meisho.
His older half-sister was Emperor Meisho.
His older half-sister was Empress Meisho.

sen.j: 典侍：庭田秀子
sen.e: Naishi no suke (a court lady of the first rank) : Hideko NIWATA

sen.e: Naishi no suke (a court lady of the first rank): Hideko NIWATA
Naishi no suke (a court lady of the first rank): Hideko NIWATA

sen.j: 第一皇女：孝子内親王（礼成門院）
sen.e: The first Princess : Princess Koshi (Reisei mon in)
The first princess, Koshi (Reisei mon-in)
The first princess: Imperial Princess Koshi (Reiseimonin)

sen.j: 寛永19年（1642年）に立太子、翌年に姉・明正天皇の譲位を受けて即位。
sen.e: In 1642 he became Crown Prince, and enthroned after his sister, Emperor Meisho abdicated on the following year.
In 1642 he became the crown prince, and he was enthroned the following year after the abdication of his sister, Emperor Meisho.
In 1642 he became the crown prince, and he was enthroned the following year after the abdication of his sister, Empress Meisho.

sen.j: 在位期間は、ちょうど、徳川家光から徳川家綱の時代にあたる。
sen.e: During his reign, the government was changed from Ieyasu TOKUGAWA force to Ietsuna TOKUGAWA force.
During his reign, the government was changed from an Ieyasu TOKUGAWA force to an Ietsuna TOKUGAWA force.
During his reign, the government was changed from an Ieyasu TOKUGAWA force to an Ietsuna TOKUGAWA force.

sen.j: 激しい性格の持ち主で剣術を好み、諫言した京都所司代板倉重宗に「武士の切腹は見たことがないから、腹を切って見せよ。
sen.e: It is said he had a strong personality and loved swordplay, one occasion when the shogunate's military governor stationed in Kyoto, Shigemune ITAKURA remonstrated to him, the Emperor said to Shigemune, 'I have never seen Samusai hara-kiri, why don't you show me right now'

It is said that he had a strong personality and loved swordplay: on one occasion, when the shogunate's military governor was stationed in Kyoto, Shigemune ITAKURA remonstrated the Emperor, who said to Shigemune, 'I have never seen a samurai commit hara-kiri, so why don't you show me right now?'

It is said the Emperor had a strong personality and loved swordplay: on one occasion, when Shigemune ITAKURA, the shogunate's military governor who was stationed in Kyoto, remonstrated the Emperor, he said to Shigemune, 'I have never seen samurai commit seppuku (suicide by disembowelment), so why don't you show me right now?'
sen.cmt: 一部文法を修正しました。切腹 の補足を追加しました。

sen.j: 」と言い放つなど、江戸幕府に対しても抵抗していたと伝えられている。
sen.e: It is said he was against Edo government.
It is said that he was against the Edo government.
It is said that he was against the Edo government.

sen.j: 一方、学問好きであり、儒者藤原惺窩（せいか）の影響を受け、朱子学にのめり込んでいた。
sen.e: On the other hand he loved studies, he had a passion to study the doctrines of Zhu Xi, influenced by Seika FUJIWARA.
On the other hand, he loved studies and had a passion for the doctrines of Zhu Xi, who was influenced by Seika FUJIWARA.
On the other hand, he loved studies and had a passion for the doctrines of Zhu Xi, under the influence of a Confucian, Seika FUJIWARA.

sen.j: 承応3年（1654年）、天然痘の為22歳で崩御。
sen.e: In 1654 he died of smallpox when he was twenty two years old.
He died of smallpox in 1654, at age 22.
He died of smallpox in 1654, at age twenty-two.
sen.cmt: 数字をスペルアウトしました。

sen.j: 突然の死は毒殺などと取り沙汰された。
sen.e: There was a rumor that he was poisoned by someone since he died suddenly.
There was a rumor that he had been intentionally poisoned, since he had died suddenly.
There was a rumor that he had been intentionally poisoned, since he had died suddenly.

sen.j: ただし、前年から体調を崩しており、廷臣達と末弟の識仁親王（後の霊元天皇）を養子に迎える相談をしていたとする記録もある。
sen.e: However he had not been well from the previous year of his heath, there was a record that the Emperor discussed with his close aides about adopting the youngest brother, Prince Satohito. (later called Emperor Reigen)

However, his health had been poor since the previous year, and there was a record that the Emperor, together with his close aides, discussed the idea of adopting the youngest brother, Prince Satohito (later called Emperor Reigen).

However, his health had been poor since the previous year, and there was a record that the Emperor, together with his close aides, discussed the idea of adopting the youngest brother, Imperial Prince Satohito (later called Emperor Reigen).

sen.e: He was entombed in Tsukino wa no misasagi at Senzan-cho Town, Imagumano, Higashiyama Ward, Kyoto City.
He was entombed in Tsukino wa no misasagi at Senzan-cho Town, Imagumano, in the Higashiyama Ward of Kyoto City.

sen.j: 尚、後光明天皇の崩御以降、天皇の遺体を土葬することが復活し、歴代に直せば、後水尾天皇以降の天皇は皆土葬された。
sen.e: After Emperor Go-Komyo died, burying deceased person's body under the earth was brought back, in successive years all the Emperors after Go-Mizunoo were buried under the earth.
After Emperor Go-Komyo died, the tradition of burying a deceased person's body in the earth was revived, and in successive years all the emperors after Go-Mizunoo were buried in the ground.
After Emperor Gokomyo died, the tradition of burying a deceased person's body in the earth was revived, and in successive years all the emperors after Gomizunoo were buried in the ground.
